title: My monthly post about disgusting club tags
body:
I'll keep it concise, I've made my point enough in previous posts. Its not a hard one to explain.

I CONSTANTLY see club tags with homophobic, racist, culturally insensitive, and hateful connotations. Probably in about 3-4 out of every 10 games, someone's got an offensive club tag. Pick a condemnable word, and I've seen it used as a club tag in one way or another.

If riot claims they have a zero tolerance stance on these types of behavior in chat, and in summoner names - why is it allowed in club tags? Futhermore, why do I have no option to report it in-game? I have to resort to using a third party screenshot app and navigate through an entire (poorly designed) support website to get things taken care of, and even then I get copy/paste generic responses and no guarantee anyone did anything about it.

Also, riot needs to step up their game as far as summoner name and club tag filtering. Its not hard to prevent things like N!gger and fa g0t. I'm a 400-level computer science student and I know how to do it, so I'd hope that professional game designers would have the same or better knowledge.

The problem with disallowing hate-speech is that by creating a law(in a government setting) that makes hate-speech illegal, that also makes free-speech in itself illegal.

For example: American revolution.

If one said they were going to form a militia out loud in public in front of an officer, that person and anyone affiliated would be likely to be put into jail.

That type of speech was considered hate speech to the British while being Revolutionary and Patriotic to the 13 Colonies.

That's where the problem of free speech VS. hate speech comes in, who specifically decides and defines the rules of speech?

Leaving rules of speech vague allows for misuse of those rules. Ex: Person X and person Y are sitting side by side debating some topic about economics.

Person X supports one side and person Y supports the other.  

Once person X or person Y feels like their argument won't be able to stand up to the other person's argument, they can simply state that the argument made was "hate speech" and thereby should disqualify that argument.

In other words, Making rules against hate speech in which specific people have to define it by themselves allows free speech to no longer be free.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8xGekzN6EuM

And a law that makes murder illegal also makes freedom itself illegal.

If there was a law banning the use of "Hateful words" in which anyone found using a "Hateful word" would be punished by up to 2 years in prison, the problem arises when one can simply say that the law in question is using "Hateful words" whether or not it IS; that law would be forced, by it's own rulings, to repeal itself.

The fact of the matter remains that, WHO defines the exact line between Hate speech?
